0.00.text: Hi everyone, my name is Rebekah

1.30.text: and welcome back to this week's episode of TJLC Explained

4.36.text: where I'll be talking about the Blind Banker in depth.

6.76.text: If you're not super enthusiastic for this one, I can't say that I blame you

10.00.text: For a long time I thought this episode was terrible.

12.85.text:
The structure seemed awkward, everyone
seemed to be acting out of character

16.06.text:
the case wasn't particularly interesting
and in the end nothing happens other

19.38.text:
than to get John and Sherlock back to the
point where they end off A Study in Pink.

22.76.text:
I was wrong though and if you'll stick with
me I'll explain how this episode

25.65.text:
actually serves to further the romantic
arc and how, subtextually, it foreshadows

29.55.text:
a lot of what is going to happen in future
series. I still haven't gone too in-depth

33.38.text: into what mirroring is and since I'm going to be referencing it heavily throughout

36.78.text: this episode I feel like I should explain what I'm talking about.

39.30.text: Mirroring is a literary device where the actions and characteristics of a side character

42.89.text:
intentionally parallel those of a main
character in order to reveal something about them.

46.80.text: This is sort of similar to a foil where a side character exists to highlight

50.39.text:
the differences between them and the
main character. Both mirrors and foils are

53.58.text: used all the time on Sherlock.

55.74.text:
Almost every side character parallels
either Sherlock or John. I'm planning a

59.28.text:
video covering this more in depth in the
future, but knowing that Soo-Lin is a mirror

62.56.text:
for Sherlock is crucial to understanding
this episode. She'll say and do things

66.08.text:
that Sherlock can't and reveal what
he's actually feeling. The episode

69.30.text:
actually opens by introducing Soo-Lin.
This is a weird choice if you don't know

72.62.text:
that Soo-Lin is a mirror for Sherlock. If you do,
this first scene lays the groundwork for

76.23.text:
setting up Sherlock's emotional state
in this episode. This episode actually

79.36.text: opens on a close-up of the teapots

88.70.text:
In my last video I actually went in-depth explaining
how tea symbolizes gay love on Sherlock

92.84.text:
and if you know that opening with the
teapots is another subtle clue for the

96.10.text:
focus of the episode. We can actually
look at the teapots to represent the

99.03.text:
Sherlock Holmes stories and their
adaptations.

104.10.text:
the more the tea pot is used, the more beautiful it
becomes.

108.95.text: The original stories have only benefited from being retold so many times.

112.48.text:
"The pot" is seasoned by
repeatedly pouring "tea" over the surface

116.20.text:
which leaves a beautiful shine and this
process of making "tea" to shine the pots has

120.10.text:
been happening for centuries. Soo-Lin is
approached by a young man asking her out.

123.49.text:
Even though she's a bit reserved, it's
clear she returns his interest.

126.59.text: Some things aren't supposed to sit behind glass. They're made to be touched,

135.07.text:
Soo-Lin mentions that the "tea pots" are in
desperate need of attention, because not

138.45.text: enough tea has been made in them.

144.74.text: Well I can't see how a tiny splash of tea's gonna help.

148.53.text: Sometimes you have to look hard at something to see its value

152.57.text: This exchange here mirrors the conversation at Angelo's

154.96.text:
and here we can see Sherlock's feelings
more clearly than we could there.

158.18.text: He was interested in John but was afraid of being hurt.

160.92.text: I don't suppose that you want to have a drink?

165.96.text:
In a pub with me,
tonight.

171.50.text: You wouldn't like me all that much

174.96.text: Can I maybe decide that for myself?

176.88.text:
Andy is a bit more forward than John was, but he doesn't have to deal with internalized
homophobia

181.26.text: . Even though Soo-Lin is interested in Andy, she turns him down because she is worried

184.30.text: that a relationship would be dangerous to both of them

193.80.text: She shuts away the tea pots as she's doing this.

196.04.text: This bit foreshadows Sherlock's feelings in season 2, but more on that later.

199.64.text:
What matters now is that Soo-Lin is
definitely giving off signs that she's

202.54.text: interested and when Andy proceeds to ask her out, Soo-Lin would readily go out with him

206.05.text:
if she weren't in danger. At this
point Sherlock isn't in danger so we can

209.36.text:
assume that if John were to ever ask him
out again, Sherlock would readily take him up

212.73.text:
on his offer and that he's been trying
to make that happen. This reading makes

215.80.text:
their first exchanges make much more
sense. At the start of the episode

219.15.text: John is out buying groceries while Sherlock is taking care of an exciting case

You could easily be forgiven for taking this as a sign
that the instant connection that John

237.78.text:
and Sherlock shared in the first episode has
been lost here due to poor writing

242.37.text:
Sherlock knows John is bored by civilian
routine and that he would instantly jump

246.07.text:
at the opportunity to be part of an
exciting case. He said so himself with

249.23.text:
the "I said dangerous and here you are"
exchange and he has used that to his advantage

252.36.text:
to lure John back into the case more
than once, so if he isn't including John

256.13.text:
it's a deliberate choice and why would
he be doing that? What reason could he

259.52.text:
possibly have for cutting John off of
the adrenaline he so desperately craves

262.97.text: while being increasingly warm, making sure he looks particularly nice

271.50.text: and hanging around the flat all the time.

273.18.text:
He's obviously winding John up, hoping
that eventually the pressure will cause

276.64.text:
John to act out on the feelings he showed at
Angelo's. Don't wanna take my word for it?

1365.44.text: John: Yeah, well at least I would, if I can get to my pockets.

1380.26.text: John's getting worn out by this point, but still readily follows Sherlock back to the museum.

When they talk to Andy, Sherlock's attention instantly goes to
the tea pots. Of course.

1397.98.text:
Andy: The pots were her  obsession. um,
they need urgent work if, if they dry out

1402.32.text:
then the clay can start to crumble, apparently you have to just
keep making tea in them.

1406.72.text:
Going back to the tea pots as the original stories, it's not
just that making tea in them makes them

1410.65.text:
more beautiful but that without tea,
they would crumble. Sherlock realizes

1413.87.text:
from the fact that another one is shining
that Soo Lin has been sneaking back in to

1417.09.text:
work on them. They wait for her to show
up. When Sherlock surprises her, Soo Lin almost

1420.66.text:
drops the pot nearly, shattering
centuries of work. Sherlock saves it though.

1425.46.text: Sherlock: Fancy a biscuit with that?

1429.76.text: Sherlock: Centuries old, don't wanna break that.

1440.28.text: Soo Lin's backstory is laden with foreshadowing.

1443.14.text: for example the person coming after her.

1445.02.text: Soo Lin: Zhi Zhu. John: Zhi Zhu?

1449.32.text: Sherlock: James Moriarty isn't a man at all, he's a spider.

1453.32.text: Sherlock clearly empathizes with Soo Lin, and openly shows concern for her while she's speaking.

1457.52.text:
Like Soo Lin, Sherlock was
involved with drugs at a young age

1460.22.text:
although he was using rather than
smuggling. There's an intentional cut to John

1463.68.text:
when Soo Lin talks about putting
all that behind her showing that Sherlock

1466.60.text: started a new phase when John entered his life.

to England.

1498.76.text: They are never very far away.

Now this is where it gets really interesting.
some of you will have heard of M theory.

the theory that Mycroft has been working
for Moriarty against his will.

1527.02.text:
this scene would seem to confirm that
theory.

Neither Mycroft or Moriarty are the ones really in charge
though.

Soo Lin betrays Zhi Zhu by not being like

This works for either Moriarity or

1565.97.text:
careful planning that is clearly going
into this blows my mind.

He's only kind to her while she's looking. With John he's

They stay up all night working and john has officially
spent all of his energy on Sherlock.

1690.84.text:
He has nothing left to give to his mundane job,
or the woman working there and falls asleep on duty.

1709.49.text: When he eventually wakes up, Sarah rightly assumes that he's tired because of a romantic interest.

1718.88.text: John: Uh, I was ah, attending a sort of book event.

1747.22.text: and get some air with him

1755.54.text:
about the fact that he's changed his mind about a
relationship only it's at the worst possible time.

1773.84.text: Even if Sherlock was being serious, which he definitely wasn't

1776.42.text: now is the worst possible time for him to bring out the possibility of a relationship.

1779.90.text: Now that John is finally moving on.

1782.18.text: I really wish John had taken a moment to think about it though.

Sherlock starts thinking he's
misread John's interest and pivots to asking where John is going.

for one night only.

advice.

Sherlock actually shows up to third wheel so
intensely

This isn't about the case. Remember this is the first case he's

and before he started he was jumping at the chance to

is being within touching distance of

Whilst we were running around the gallery she

2164.98.text: It's the London A to Z that they use...

2183.90.text: John is more afraid here than he normally is in these situations, but being knocked out and restrained might be bringing up bad memories from the war.

2190.06.text: Shan starts calling out John for the fact that he and Sherlock are so intertwined, that at this point they're basically the same person.

2201.98.text: Shan: Forgive me, if I do not take your word for it.

2211.00.text: Debit card, name of S. Holmes.

2215.48.text: John: Yes that's not actually mine, he lent that to me.

2218.60.text: Shan: A cheque, for five thousand pounds, made out in the name of Mr. Sherlock Holmes.

2224.32.text: John: He gave, He gave me that to, to look after.

2227.74.text: Shan: Tickets, from the theatre collected by you, name of Holmes.

2232.76.text: Box office attendant: Whats the name? John: Uh, Holmes.

2234.18.text: John: I realize what this looks like, but I'm not him.

2237.96.text: Shan: We heard it from your own mouth. John: What?

2241.64.text: Shan: I am Sherlock Holmes, and I always work alone.

2245.58.text: John: Because no one else can compete with my massive intellect.

2248.52.text: John: Did I really say that?

2250.80.text: If you see Shan as a parallell for Mary this bit is even more poignant. Here's another interesting connection.

2258.02.text: Shan: Three times we tried to kill you, and your companion Mr. Holmes.

2263.32.text: Moriarty: Sorry boys. I'm sooo changeable!

2267.56.text: Moriarty: Okay... Let me give you a little extra incentive.

2273.57.text: Your friends will die if you don't.

2279.06.text: Mary: Is John with you? Sherlock: He's um.

2286.98.text: Magnussen: So, what do you do now?

2292.90.text: Sherlock: Mary, whatever he's got on you, let me help.

2297.62.text: Mary: Oh Sherlock if you take one more step, I swear I will kill you.

2301.20.text: Sherlock: No Mrs. Watson, you won't.

2308.16.text: Rather than meaning that Mary and Moriarty haven't been trying to kill Sherlock and John up until this point

2313.10.text: It means that what's to come is even worse

2315.18.text: Almost losing John causes Sherlock to re-evaluate. He stares at the London Eye

2318.73.text:
lit up with gay pride colors and decides
to tell John about his feelings

2328.62.text: That's why he's trying extra hard to be cool when he shows up at the tramway.

2337.14.text: Sherlock Holmes is nothing at all like him.

2340.44.text: How would you describe me John?

2348.14.text: Sherlock: That's a semi-automatic, you fire it the bullet will travel a little over a thousand meters per second.

2354.78.text: Sherlock: Well, the radius curvature of these walls is nearly four meters. If you miss the bullet will ricochet.

2362.08.text: Might even bounce off the tunnel and hit you .

2364.42.text: Mary: You were very slow. Sherlock: How good a shot are you?

2370.82.text: Mary: How badly do you want to find out?

2373.26.text: Sherlock: If I die here my body will be found in a building with your face projected on the front of it. Even Scotland Yard could get somewhere with that.

2381.62.text: John is the one to kill Zhi Zhu.

2403.30.text: Some people take this to mean that Mycroft will end up dying.

2405.88.text: But remember, this is a parallel where Sherlock is dead as well, and that definitely isn't going to be happening.

2410.22.text: I think it's much more likely that this means that John will be the one to kill the person threatening his love interest.

2414.76.text: At that point, it will be Sherlock.

2416.60.text: Sherlock is comforting to Sarah, showing his compassionate side.

2419.38.text:
and proving that his issue with her earlier wasn't the fact
that he's unsociable.

2422.44.text: John however, continues to be terrible.

2437.78.text: John: Don't worry... next date won't be like this.

2444.42.text: Sherlock is disappointed at how the night went, but at least they get to have tea together the next day.

2450.67.text:
message they were trying to reclaim or
JP in with nine million pounds bring it

2455.86.text: John: Million yes. Nine million for Jade Pin. Dragon Den Black Tramway.

2466.72.text: Sherlock: Worth nine million pounds, bring it to the tramway, their London hideout.

2472.92.text: Sherlock: Apparently. John: Why so much?

Sherlock: Didn't know its value, just
thought it would suit you.

2491.02.text: Amanda: Oh my god! Oh my

John gets the chance to show up
Sebastian too.

2502.76.text: Sebastian: He really climbed up onto the balcony? John: Nail a plank across the window and all your problems are over.

2512.78.text: All is well. Even though there's Sarah now, John and Sherlock end the episode back in sync.

2517.44.text: John: over a thousand years old, and it's sitting on her bedside table every night.

2521.34.text: Sherlock: He didn't know its value, didn't know why they were chasing him.

2525.72.text: John: Should have just got her a lucky cat.

2528.52.text: More or less. Sherlock is still distracted.

2531.70.text: John: You mind, don't you? Sherlock: What?

2537.42.text: General Shan. It's not enough that we got her two henchmen.

2541.14.text: Sherlock: It must be a vast network John. Thousands of operatives.

2544.24.text: You and I, we've barely scratched the surface.

2547.26.text:
John: You cracked the code though, Sherlock. And maybe Dimmock can track down all of them now
that he knows it.

2552.16.text: Sherlock: No, no. I cracked this code. All the smugglers have to do is pick up another book.

2559.22.text: Even though he cracked one code, it wasn't enough.

2562.30.text: John looks outside to see more symbols being set up.

2564.80.text:
They haven't
scratched the surface yet.

2574.53.text: Which starts the transition to the next episode.

2576.73.text: Shan is speaking to an anonymous "M"

2578.42.text:
who is presumably Moriarty, but the ambiguity of that
initial is important.

2582.00.text: There are a lot of "M"s floating around

2588.52.text: Shan: I will not reveal your identity.

2600.76.text: If you think Shan, the woman leading the operation, is a parallell for Mary, the identity of her killer has interesting implications.

2606.66.text: But if they're all ultimately working for Mary, It has the same message. Mary will end up getting herself killed.

2611.48.text: It might even be Mycroft, finally redeeming himself by pulling free of her control.

2615.89.text: Whoever this "M" is, this scene shows us that Sherlock and John still have far greater threats to face.

2620.83.text: It makes sense that an episode that centers around symbols and codes would have a heavy amount of subtext going on,

2625.47.text:
even for an episode of Sherlock. On the surface layer
a lot of the choices made in the episode

2629.57.text:
might look like poor writing, but with a
knowledge of mirrors and drink code it

2632.81.text:
it becomes obvious that the episode
exists to set up plans they've had from the

2635.55.text:
very beginning. And even the apparently
inconsistent actions of the main

2638.61.text: characters fit perfectly into place when you take these things into consideration and take a closer look.

2644.78.text:
Placement-wise it make sense to foreshadow
the entire series in the second episode

2648.28.text: especially if they want to pull their whole "you were told and you didn't listen" shtick later on.

2652.52.text: But the fact that they had the overarching plot of their story

2654.86.text:
planned out to this degree from the very
beginning is seriously impressive

2658.28.text:
and all of the foreshadowing here makes me even
more excited to see the eventual conclusion unfold.

on to "The Great Game" so stick around for
